page.title: Human rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1:
'''[[Human rights]] in the [[Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|post-Mubarak transition]]''' have been the subject of concerns and controversies since the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]]. The '''[[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] (SCAF)''' ({{lang-ar|Ø§ÙÙØ¬ÙØ³ Ø§ÙØ£Ø¹ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙØ§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­Ø©}}, ''{{transl|ar|DIN|al-MaÇ§lis al-Ê¾AÊ¿lÄ lil-QuwwÄt al-Musallaá¸¥ah}}'' have been the focus of [[Human rights in Egypt|human rights]] [[Human rights violations|concerns]]. The SCAF, which consists of a body of 20<ref name=sis>{{cite web| url=http://www.sis.gov.eg/En/LastPage.aspx?Category_ID=1136| author=Egypt State Information Service| title=Formation of the Armed Forces Supreme Council.| date=14 February 2011}} Archived at webcite at http://www.webcitation.org/5wTMNq7Mb</ref> senior officers in the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|Egyptian military]], was handed the power to govern [[Egypt]] after the ouster of [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] on 11 February 2011<ref name=globe>{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/the-new-face-of-power-in-cairo/article1904700/ |author=The Globe and Mail |title=The New Face of Power in Egypt. |date=11 February 2011| accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref><ref name=wt>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/11/crowds-rejoice-egypts-mubarak-steps-down/ |author=Murdock, Heather |title=Crowds rejoice as Egyptâs Mubarak steps down, hands power to military| publisher=[[The Washington Times]]| date=11 February 2011| accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> as a consequence of the 2011 Egyptian revolution.
'''[[Human rights]] in the [[Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|post-Mubarak transition]]''' have been the subject of concerns and controversies since the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]]. The '''[[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] (SCAF)''' ({{lang-ar|Ø§ÙÙØ¬ÙØ³ Ø§ÙØ£Ø¹ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙØ§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­Ø©}}, ''{{transl|ar|DIN|al-MaÇ§lis al-Ê¾AÊ¿lÄ lil-QuwwÄt al-Musallaá¸¥ah}}'' have been the focus of [[Human rights in Egypt|human rights]] [[Human rights violations|concerns]]. The SCAF, which consists of a body of 20<ref name=sis>{{cite web| url=http://www.sis.gov.eg/En/LastPage.aspx?Category_ID=1136| author=Egypt State Information Service| title=Formation of the Armed Forces Supreme Council.| date=14 February 2011}} Archived at webcite at http://www.webcitation.org/5wTMNq7Mb</ref> senior officers in the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|Egyptian military]], was handed the power to govern [[Egypt]] after the ouster of [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] on 11 February 2011<ref name=globe>{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/the-new-face-of-power-in-cairo/article1904700/ |author=The Globe and Mail |title=The New Face of Power in Egypt. |date=11 February 2011| accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref><ref name=wt>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/11/crowds-rejoice-egypts-mubarak-steps-down/ |author=Murdock, Heather |title=Crowds rejoice as Egyptâs Mubarak steps down, hands power to military| publisher=[[The Washington Times]]| date=11 February 2011| accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> as a consequence of the 2011 Egyptian revolution.
â   â
==Censorship==
  â
[[File:Ganzeer.jpg|thumb|Mohammed Fahmy AKA Ganzeer, the graffiti artist who designed the sticker on the t-shirt and got arrested for posting it in [[Tahrir Square]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0526/Egyptian-graffiti-artist-Ganzeer-arrested-amid-surge-in-political-expression |title=Egyptian graffiti artist Ganzeer arrested amid surge in political expression |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref>]]
  â   â
Ganzeer (graffiti artist), [[Aida El Kashief]] (film director) , and Abdel Rahman Amin AKA NadimX (Abdel Rahman Amin) were arrested<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/5/35/13024/Arts--Culture/Stage--Street/CIC-condemns-arrest-of-artists-by-military-.aspx |title=CIC condemns arrest of artists by military - Stage & Street - Arts & Culture - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> for posting a poster that offended the military police. They were released later that day.<ref>{{cite web|author=New York Times, USA |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/27/egypt-gearing-up-for-a-second-revolutionary-round/ |title=Egypt: Gearing Up for a Second Revolutionary Round Â· Global Voices |publisher=Globalvoicesonline.org |date=27 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> "I donât know why we were transferred to the military prosecution" said graffiti artist Mohamed Fahmy, a 29-year-old Egyptian artist,<ref>{{cite web|author=Jack Shenker in Cairo |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/may/19/egypts-uprising-diy-art-cairo-streets |title=Egypt's uprising brings DIY spirit out on to the streets | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> who goes by Ganzeer on Twitter, minutes after his release. He said that will in custody That he and others talk about "politics and democracy".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/graffiti-artist-says-online-outcry-may-have-sped-up-release.html |title=Graffiti artist says online outcry may have sped up release |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/05/26/egypts-youth-vocal-against-army |title=Egypt's youth vocal against army | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Another activist who was detained after the ousting of Mubarak was Maikel Nabil Sanad.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maikelnabil.com/2010/12/my-cv.html |title=About me |publisher=http://www.maikelnabil.com/ |date=5 December 2010 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> Sanad is a political activist and blogger, and in April 2009 he founded the "No to Compulsory Military Service Movement". As a pacifist, he declared his conscientious objection, and demanded to be exempted from military service. He was arrested on 12 November 2010 by military police but was released two days later, and finally exempted from military service on medical grounds. Sanad participated actively in the Egyptian revolution, and especially highlighted the fact that Egypt has effectively been ruled by the military for six decades. He was arrested on 4 February by military police and tortured, but released 27 hours later. He was arrested in his home in the Ain Shams neighbourhood in Cairo at about 10PM on 28 March 2011 by military police. He was only able to call his brother on the next day, to inform him of his arrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wri-irg.org/node/12513 |title=Egyptian Pacifist Maikel Nabil Sanad Arrested for Insulting Military |publisher=http://www.wri-irg.org/ |date=30 March 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> Sanad was sentenced to three years' imprisonment on charges of "insulting the military" in his post "The Army and The People Were Never One Hand"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maikelnabil.com/2011/03/army-and-people-wasnt-ever-one-hand.html |title=The Army and The People Wasn't Ever One Hand |publisher=http://www.maikelnabil.com/ |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> by the 10th of Ramadan military court in Nasr City near Cairo on 10 April 2011. Before, he was imprisoned in a special punishment cell at El Marg prison, which did not allow him to see any sun light. In addition, his cell mates threatened him. Sanad demanded to see a doctor, as he suffers from unstable blood pressure and needs regular medication and medical attention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wri-irg.org/node/13004 |title=Imprisoned Pacifist Blogger Maikel Nabil Sanad in Solitary Confinement |publisher=http://www.wri-irg.org/ |date=23 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Egyptian blogger and activist [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]], television host [[Reem Maged]] and journalist [[Nabil Sharaf El-Din]] were given a summons on 30 May 2011 to appear before military prosecution after Maged brought Hamalawy on her show where he criticized the role of military police, holding the head of the military police responsible for torturing activists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/13270/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-journalists-to-be-questioned-tomorrow-by-.aspx |title=Egyptian journalists to be questioned tomorrow by military for denouncing the torture of activists - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref> They were released Tuesday after "chatting" with Military Prosecution and Hossam el-Hamalawy was asked to hand reports of army abuses to authorities.<ref name="DailyEgypt">{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/blogger-asked-to-hand-reports-of-army-abuses-to-authorities.html |title=Blogger asked to hand reports of army abuses to authorities |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Egyptian blogger and activist [[Rasha Azab]] and [[El Fagr]] newspaper Editor in Chief [[Adel Hammouda]] have been summoned by military prosecution. They are to appear before military prosecutors on 19 June 2011.<ref name="ahram1">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/14532.aspx |title=Journalists Rasha Azab and Adel Hammouda summoned by Egypt's military prosecution - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-06-18}}</ref> Azab published an article in El Fagr newspaper detailing the meeting that took place between members of the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces (SCAF) and the No to Military Trials campaigners.<ref name="ahram1"/>
 
==Military trials==
==Military trials==
Line 29: Line 18:
[[File:Ramy Essam.jpg|thumb|Ramy Essam]]
[[File:Ramy Essam.jpg|thumb|Ramy Essam]]
Ramy Essam, the 23-year-old Egyptian student and musician, was arrest and tortured by the army police on 9 March 2011.<ref name="CNN">{{cite web|author=By Â Reza Sayah, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/17/egypt.activists/index.html |title=Pro-democracy activists allege torture by Egyptian soldiers - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=18 March 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref> Without warning, the army stormed the [[Tahrir Square|square]], ripping down tents and arresting more than 100 people, including Ramy Essam.<ref name="NPR"/> He says men in army uniforms dragged him to the Egyptian National Museum, which had become a security headquarters.<ref name="NPR"/> He says the men took him to a courtyard, stripped him to his shorts, and started torturing Ramy Essam.<ref name="NPR"/> "They took off my clothes. They used sticks, metal rods, wires, whips." He received electric shocks, he said.<ref name="CNN"/> "There was a soldier who would jump in the air and land on my face with his legs".<ref name="CNN"/> Ramy Essam is best known as the singer of the Egyptian revolution due to his popular music during the Egyptian uprising against Hosni Mubarak.<ref name="NPR">{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/03/15/134538629/ramy-esam-the-singer-of-the-egyptian-revolution |title=Ramy Essam: The Singer Of The Egyptian Revolution |publisher=NPR |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref>
Ramy Essam, the 23-year-old Egyptian student and musician, was arrest and tortured by the army police on 9 March 2011.<ref name="CNN">{{cite web|author=By Â Reza Sayah, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/17/egypt.activists/index.html |title=Pro-democracy activists allege torture by Egyptian soldiers - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=18 March 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref> Without warning, the army stormed the [[Tahrir Square|square]], ripping down tents and arresting more than 100 people, including Ramy Essam.<ref name="NPR"/> He says men in army uniforms dragged him to the Egyptian National Museum, which had become a security headquarters.<ref name="NPR"/> He says the men took him to a courtyard, stripped him to his shorts, and started torturing Ramy Essam.<ref name="NPR"/> "They took off my clothes. They used sticks, metal rods, wires, whips." He received electric shocks, he said.<ref name="CNN"/> "There was a soldier who would jump in the air and land on my face with his legs".<ref name="CNN"/> Ramy Essam is best known as the singer of the Egyptian revolution due to his popular music during the Egyptian uprising against Hosni Mubarak.<ref name="NPR">{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/03/15/134538629/ramy-esam-the-singer-of-the-egyptian-revolution |title=Ramy Essam: The Singer Of The Egyptian Revolution |publisher=NPR |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
==Censorship==
  +
[[File:Ganzeer.jpg|thumb|Mohammed Fahmy AKA Ganzeer, the graffiti artist who designed the sticker on the t-shirt and got arrested for posting it in [[Tahrir Square]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0526/Egyptian-graffiti-artist-Ganzeer-arrested-amid-surge-in-political-expression |title=Egyptian graffiti artist Ganzeer arrested amid surge in political expression |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref>]]
  +   +
Ganzeer (graffiti artist), [[Aida El Kashief]] (film director) , and Abdel Rahman Amin AKA NadimX (Abdel Rahman Amin) were arrested<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/5/35/13024/Arts--Culture/Stage--Street/CIC-condemns-arrest-of-artists-by-military-.aspx |title=CIC condemns arrest of artists by military - Stage & Street - Arts & Culture - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> for posting a poster that offended the military police. They were released later that day.<ref>{{cite web|author=New York Times, USA |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/27/egypt-gearing-up-for-a-second-revolutionary-round/ |title=Egypt: Gearing Up for a Second Revolutionary Round Â· Global Voices |publisher=Globalvoicesonline.org |date=27 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> "I donât know why we were transferred to the military prosecution" said graffiti artist Mohamed Fahmy, a 29-year-old Egyptian artist,<ref>{{cite web|author=Jack Shenker in Cairo |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/may/19/egypts-uprising-diy-art-cairo-streets |title=Egypt's uprising brings DIY spirit out on to the streets | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> who goes by Ganzeer on Twitter, minutes after his release.   +   +

As a pacifist, he declared his conscientious objection, and demanded to be exempted from military service. He was arrested on 12 November 2010 by military police but was released two days later, and finally exempted from military service on medical grounds. Sanad participated actively in the Egyptian revolution, and especially highlighted the fact that Egypt has effectively been ruled by the military for six decades. He was arrested on 4 February by military police and tortured, but released 27 hours later. He was arrested in his home in the Ain Shams neighbourhood in Cairo at about 10PM on 28 March 2011 by military police. He was only able to call his brother on the next day, to inform him of his arrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wri-irg.org/node/12513 |title=Egyptian Pacifist Maikel Nabil Sanad Arrested for Insulting Military |publisher=http://www.wri-irg.org/ |date=30 March 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> Sanad was sentenced to three years' imprisonment on charges of "insulting the military" in his post "The Army and The People Were Never One Hand"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maikelnabil.com/2011/03/army-and-people-wasnt-ever-one-hand.html |title=The Army and The People Wasn't Ever One Hand |publisher=http://www.maikelnabil.com/ |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref> by the 10th of Ramadan military court in Nasr City near Cairo on 10 April 2011. Before, he was imprisoned in a special punishment cell at El Marg prison, which did not allow him to see any sun light. In addition, his cell mates threatened him. Sanad demanded to see a doctor, as he suffers from unstable blood pressure and needs regular medication and medical attention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wri-irg.org/node/13004 |title=Imprisoned Pacifist Blogger Maikel Nabil Sanad in Solitary Confinement |publisher=http://www.wri-irg.org/ |date=23 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
Egyptian blogger and activist [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]], television host [[Reem Maged]] and journalist [[Nabil Sharaf El-Din]] were given a summons on 30 May 2011 to appear before military prosecution after Maged brought Hamalawy on her show where he criticized the role of military police, holding the head of the military police responsible for torturing activists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/13270/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-journalists-to-be-questioned-tomorrow-by-.aspx |title=Egyptian journalists to be questioned tomorrow by military for denouncing the torture of activists - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref> They were released Tuesday after "chatting" with Military Prosecution and Hossam el-Hamalawy was asked to hand reports of army abuses to authorities.<ref name="DailyEgypt">{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/blogger-asked-to-hand-reports-of-army-abuses-to-authorities.html |title=Blogger asked to hand reports of army abuses to authorities |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref>
